thoughts.summary: Explaining equivalence relation with cancellation property
thoughts.content: To define an equivalence relation on pairs \((a, b)\) and \((c, d)\), we say \((a, b) \sim (c, d)\) if \(ad = bc\). It’s reflexive since \(ab = ba\), and symmetric is obvious. For transitivity, if \((a, b) \sim (c, d)\) and \((c, d) \sim (e, f)\), multiplying gives \(af = be\), and we show that \((a, b) \sim (e, f)\), using the cancellation property of integers.

Here is a **drop-in section** you can paste **as-is** just before `\end{document}` (it does not require modifying any existing content, and it explicitly leverages Theorem `\ref{thm2.1}` and Proposition `\ref{pro1.4.2}`).

```latex
% ============================================================
\newpage
\section{Equivalence Relations, Equivalence Classes, Congruence Arithmetic}

\noindent
In earlier sections, we repeatedly grouped integers according to the remainder they leave upon division by a fixed positive integer. This idea can be formalized cleanly using the language of \emph{relations} and, in particular, \emph{equivalence relations}. The payoff is that many ``case-by-case remainder'' arguments become a single line of \emph{congruence arithmetic}.

\bigskip

\subsection*{Relations, domain, and range}

\begin{defn}[Relation] \index{relation}
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets. A \textbf{(binary) relation} $R$ from $A$ to $B$ is any subset
\[
R \subseteq A \times B.
\]
If $(a,b)\in R$, we also write $a\,R\,b$. If $A=B$, we say $R$ is a relation \textbf{on} $A$.
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}[Domain and range] \index{domain of a relation}\index{range of a relation}
Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item The \textbf{domain} of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\{\, a\in A \ : \ \exists\, b\in B \text{ such that } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\item The \textbf{range} (also called the \textbf{image}) of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Ran}(R)=\{\, b\in B \ : \ \exists\, a\in A \text{ such that } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\end{itemize}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}
Let $R\subseteq \mathbb{R}\times \mathbb{R}$ be defined by $x\,R\,y \iff x^2+y^2=1$. Then
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\operatorname{Ran}(R)=[-1,1].
\]
Indeed, $x$ appears in some pair $(x,y)$ with $x^2+y^2=1$ if and only if $x^2\le 1$, i.e.\ $x\in[-1,1]$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{rem}
A function $f:A\to B$ is a special type of relation $R\subseteq A\times B$ in which each $a\in A$ appears in \emph{exactly one} ordered pair $(a,b)$. For general relations, an element of the domain may be related to many (or no) elements in $B$.
\end{rem}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Equivalence relations and equivalence classes}

\begin{defn}[Equivalence relation] \index{equivalence relation}\index{reflexive}\index{symmetric}\index{transitive}
Let $A$ be a set and let $\sim$ be a relation on $A$. We say that $\sim$ is an \textbf{equivalence relation} if it satisfies:
\begin{description}
\item[(E1) Reflexive:] $a\sim a$ for all $a\in A$.
\item[(E2) Symmetric:] If $a\sim b$, then $b\sim a$.
\item[(E3) Transitive:] If $a\sim b$ and $b\sim c$, then $a\sim c$.
\end{description}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}[Same sign on $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$]
On $A=\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$ define $x\sim y$ if $xy>0$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item Reflexive: $x^2>0$ for $x\neq 0$, so $x\sim x$.
\item Symmetric: $xy>0$ implies $yx>0$.
\item Transitive: if $xy>0$ and $yz>0$, then $x$ and $y$ have the same sign, and $y$ and $z$ have the same sign, hence $x$ and $z$ have the same sign, so $xz>0$.
\end{itemize}
There are exactly two equivalence classes: the positive reals and the negative reals.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Difference by a rational number]
On $A=\mathbb{R}$ define $x\sim y$ if $x-y\in \mathbb{Q}$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item Reflexive: $x-x=0\in\mathbb{Q}$.
\item Symmetric: if $x-y\in\mathbb{Q}$ then $y-x=-(x-y)\in\mathbb{Q}$.
\item Transitive: if $x-y\in\mathbb{Q}$ and $y-z\in\mathbb{Q}$ then $x-z=(x-y)+(y-z)\in\mathbb{Q}$.
\end{itemize}
The equivalence class of $x$ is $x+\mathbb{Q}=\{x+q:q\in\mathbb{Q}\}$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Same ``direction'' in the plane]
On $A=\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$ define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some non-zero real $\lambda$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item Reflexive: $\mathbf{u}=1\cdot \mathbf{u}$.
\item Symmetric: if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ with $\lambda\neq 0$, then $\mathbf{v}=\lambda^{-1}\mathbf{u}$.
\item Transitive: if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{v}=\mu \mathbf{w}$ with $\lambda,\mu\neq 0$, then $\mathbf{u}=(\lambda\mu)\mathbf{w}$.
\end{itemize}
Each equivalence class is a line through the origin with the origin removed.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Equivalent fractions]
Let
\[
A=\{(a,b)\in \mathbb{Z}\times \mathbb{Z} : b\neq 0\}.
\]
Define $(a,b)\sim(c,d)$ if $ad=bc$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item Reflexive: $ab=ba$.
\item Symmetric: $ad=bc$ implies $cb=da$.
\item Transitive: if $ad=bc$ and $cf=de$, then multiply the first equality by $f$:
\[
adf=bcf.
\]
Using $cf=de$, we get $bcf=bde$, so $adf=bde$. Since $d\neq 0$, cancellation gives $af=be$, i.e.\ $(a,b)\sim(e,f)$.
\end{itemize}
Each equivalence class corresponds to a rational number $a/b$; this is one way to construct $\mathbb{Q}$ from $\mathbb{Z}$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{defn}[Equivalence class] \index{equivalence class}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on a set $A$. For $a\in A$, the \textbf{equivalence class} of $a$ is
\[
[a]=\{\, x\in A : x\sim a \,\}.
\]
The set of all equivalence classes is denoted $A/{\sim}$ and is called the \textbf{quotient set}.
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Equivalence classes form a partition] \label{pro:partition} \index{partition}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item For each $a\in A$, we have $a\in [a]$, hence $[a]\neq \emptyset$.
\item For any $a,b\in A$, either $[a]=[b]$ or $[a]\cap[b]=\emptyset$.
\item Every element of $A$ lies in exactly one equivalence class. Equivalently,
\[
A=\bigcup_{a\in A}[a].
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
(1) Reflexivity gives $a\sim a$, hence $a\in[a]$.

(2) Suppose $[a]\cap[b]\neq \emptyset$. Choose $x\in[a]\cap[b]$. Then $x\sim a$ and $x\sim b$.
By symmetry, $a\sim x$, and by transitivity, $a\sim b$. Now let $y\in[a]$. Then $y\sim a$ and $a\sim b$ implies $y\sim b$ by transitivity, so $y\in[b]$. Hence $[a]\subseteq[b]$. By symmetry of the argument, $[b]\subseteq[a]$, so $[a]=[b]$.

(3) By (1), each $a$ lies in $[a]$. By (2), two distinct classes cannot overlap, so each element lies in exactly one class.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Congruences and modular arithmetic}

\begin{defn}[Congruence modulo $n$] \label{defn:congruence} \index{congruence}\index{modular arithmetic}
Let $n$ be a positive integer. For integers $a,b$, we say that \textbf{$a$ is congruent to $b$ modulo $n$}, written
\[
a \equiv b \pmod{n},
\]
if $n$ divides $a-b$, i.e.\ $n\,|\,(a-b)$.
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Congruence is an equivalence relation] \label{pro:cong_equiv}
Fix $n\in\mathbb{N}$. The relation $\equiv \pmod n$ is an equivalence relation on $\mathbb{Z}$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
\emph{Reflexive:} $a-a=0$, so $n|(a-a)$, hence $a\equiv a\pmod n$.

\emph{Symmetric:} if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then $n|(a-b)$, hence $n|-(a-b)=(b-a)$, so $b\equiv a\pmod n$ (see Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(2)).

\emph{Transitive:} if $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $b\equiv c\pmod n$, then $n|(a-b)$ and $n|(b-c)$. Therefore $n|[(a-b)+(b-c)]=(a-c)$ (see Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10) with $x=y=1$), hence $a\equiv c\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{defn}[Residue class] \index{residue class}
For $a\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $n\in\mathbb{N}$, the \textbf{congruence class} (or \textbf{residue class}) of $a$ modulo $n$ is
\[
[a]_n=\{\, x\in\mathbb{Z} : x\equiv a \pmod n \,\}.
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Description of congruence classes] \label{pro:class_description}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$ and $a\in\mathbb{Z}$. Then
\[
[a]_n=\{\, a+kn : k\in\mathbb{Z}\,\}.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
If $x\in[a]_n$, then $x\equiv a\pmod n$, so $n|(x-a)$ and hence $x-a=kn$ for some $k\in\mathbb{Z}$, i.e.\ $x=a+kn$.
Conversely, if $x=a+kn$, then $x-a=kn$ is divisible by $n$, so $x\equiv a\pmod n$ and $x\in[a]_n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{thm}[There are exactly $n$ residue classes modulo $n$] \label{thm:n_classes}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. Every integer $a$ is congruent modulo $n$ to a unique integer $r$ with $0\le r<n$. Consequently,
\[
\mathbb{Z}/\!\equiv\pmod n=\{[0]_n,[1]_n,\ldots,[n-1]_n\}.
\]
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
By the Division Algorithm (Theorem \ref{thm2.1}) applied to $a$ and $n$, there exist unique integers $q,r$ with
\[
a=qn+r,\qquad 0\le r<n.
\]
Then $a-r=qn$ is divisible by $n$, so $a\equiv r\pmod n$.

If also $a\equiv r'\pmod n$ with $0\le r'<n$, then $n|(r-r')$. But $0\le |r-r'|<n$, so the only multiple of $n$ in this range is $0$, hence $r=r'$. This proves uniqueness.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Congruence arithmetic}

\begin{pro}[Compatibility with addition and multiplication] \label{pro:cong_arith}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, then
\[
a+c \equiv b+d \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ac \equiv bd \pmod n.
\]
In particular, if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for every integer $k$,
\[
a+k \equiv b+k \pmod n,\qquad
ka \equiv kb \pmod n.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
From $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, we have $n|(a-b)$ and $n|(c-d)$.

\emph{Addition:} $(a+c)-(b+d)=(a-b)+(c-d)$, so $n$ divides the difference (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10)).

\emph{Multiplication:} 
\[
ac-bd=a(c-d)+d(a-b).
\]
Since $n|(c-d)$, we have $n|a(c-d)$ (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(5)); similarly $n|d(a-b)$. Hence $n|(ac-bd)$ by Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10).
The final statements follow by taking $d=c$ or by setting $c=d=k$.
\end{proof}

\begin{cor}[Powers preserve congruence] \label{cor:powers}
If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $m\ge 1$ is an integer, then $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{cor}

\begin{proof}
By Example \ref{ex1.4.8}, $a^m-b^m$ is divisible by $a-b$. Since $n|(a-b)$, it follows that $n|(a^m-b^m)$, i.e.\ $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}
A standard computational principle now becomes justified:
\[
\text{If } a\equiv r\pmod n,\ \text{then in calculations ``mod $n$'' you may replace $a$ by $r$.}
\]
Theorem \ref{thm:n_classes} says we can always choose $r$ with $0\le r<n$ (the unique remainder from the Division Algorithm).
\end{rem}

\small
\begin{ex}[A previously proved result in one line]
For $n\ge 1$, show that $3^{2n}+1$ is divisible by $2$ but not by $4$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} Working modulo $4$, we have $3^2=9\equiv 1\pmod 4$, hence $3^{2n}=(3^2)^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod 4$. Therefore
\[
3^{2n}+1 \equiv 1+1 \equiv 2 \pmod 4,
\]
so the number is even (divisible by $2$) but not divisible by $4$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Divisibility via congruence]
Show that $\dfrac{n(n^2+2)}{3}$ is an integer for every integer $n$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} It suffices to show $3\,|\,n(n^2+2)$, i.e.\ $n(n^2+2)\equiv 0\pmod 3$.
Note that
\[
n^3-n = n(n-1)(n+1)
\]
is a product of three consecutive integers, hence divisible by $3$ (Example \ref{ex1.4.4} with $n=3$). Thus $n^3\equiv n\pmod 3$, and so
\[
n(n^2+2)=n^3+2n \equiv n+2n = 3n \equiv 0 \pmod 3.
\]
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[A quick remainder computation]
Find the remainder of $2^{100}+3^{100}$ upon division by $5$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} Modulo $5$,
\[
2^4=16\equiv 1\pmod 5,\qquad 3^4=81\equiv 1\pmod 5.
\]
Hence $2^{100}=(2^4)^{25}\equiv 1$ and $3^{100}=(3^4)^{25}\equiv 1$, so
\[
2^{100}+3^{100}\equiv 1+1\equiv 2\pmod 5.
\]
Therefore the remainder is $2$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\small
\begin{exer} \label{exer:equiv_cong}
~
\begin{enumerate}
\item Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation. Prove that $\operatorname{Dom}(R)\subseteq A$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)\subseteq B$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}$ define $x\,R\,y \iff y=x^2$. Determine $\operatorname{Dom}(R)$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)$.
\item For each of the relations below, determine whether it is reflexive, symmetric, and/or transitive:
\begin{enumerate}
\item On $\mathbb{R}$, define $x\sim y \iff x\le y$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$, define $x\sim y \iff xy>0$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$, define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ iff $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some real $\lambda$ (allowing $\lambda=0$).
\end{enumerate}
\item Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. Prove directly that if $a\sim b$, then $[a]=[b]$.
\item Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. Prove that $a\equiv b\pmod n$ if and only if $a$ and $b$ have the same remainder upon division by $n$ (use Theorem \ref{thm2.1}).
\item Prove Corollary \ref{cor:powers} again, but this time by induction on $m$ using Proposition \ref{pro:cong_arith}.
\item Show that for any integer $x$, $x^2\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 4$. (Compare with the earlier case-splitting argument.)
\item Show that if $x$ is odd, then $x^2\equiv 1\pmod 8$.
\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $10$.
\item Show that if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for any polynomial $P(t)\in\mathbb{Z}[t]$ (integer coefficients),
\[
P(a)\equiv P(b)\pmod n.
\]
(Hint: build $P$ from additions and multiplications, and use Proposition \ref{pro:cong_arith}.)
\end{enumerate}
\end{exer}
\normalsize
% ============================================================
```

```latex
% ============================================================
\newpage
\section{Equivalence Relations, Equivalence Classes, Congruence Arithmetic}

\noindent
In earlier sections, we repeatedly grouped integers according to the remainder they leave upon division by a fixed positive integer. This idea can be formalized cleanly using the language of \emph{relations} and, in particular, \emph{equivalence relations}. The payoff is that many ``case-by-case remainder'' arguments become a single line of \emph{congruence arithmetic}.

\bigskip

\subsection*{Relations, domain, and range}

\begin{defn}[Relation] \index{relation}
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets. A \textbf{(binary) relation} $R$ from $A$ to $B$ is any subset
\[
R \subseteq A \times B.
\]
If $(a,b)\in R$, we also write $a\,R\,b$. If $A=B$, we say $R$ is a relation \textbf{on} $A$.
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}[Domain and range] \index{domain of a relation}\index{range of a relation}
Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item The \textbf{domain} of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\{\, a\in A \ : \ \exists\, b\in B \text{ such that } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\item The \textbf{range} (also called the \textbf{image}) of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Ran}(R)=\{\, b\in B \ : \ \exists\, a\in A \text{ such that } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\end{itemize}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}
Let $R\subseteq \mathbb{R}\times \mathbb{R}$ be defined by $x\,R\,y \iff x^2+y^2=1$. Then
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\operatorname{Ran}(R)=[-1,1].
\]
Indeed, $x$ appears in some pair $(x,y)$ with $x^2+y^2=1$ if and only if $x^2\le 1$, i.e.\ $x\in[-1,1]$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{rem}
A function $f:A\to B$ is a special type of relation $R\subseteq A\times B$ in which each $a\in A$ appears in \emph{exactly one} ordered pair $(a,b)$. For general relations, an element of the domain may be related to many (or no) elements in $B$.
\end{rem}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Equivalence relations and equivalence classes}

\begin{defn}[Equivalence relation] \index{equivalence relation}\index{reflexive}\index{symmetric}\index{transitive}
Let $A$ be a set and let $\sim$ be a relation on $A$. We say that $\sim$ is an \textbf{equivalence relation} if it satisfies:
\begin{description}
\item[(E1) Reflexive:] $a\sim a$ for all $a\in A$.
\item[(E2) Symmetric:] If $a\sim b$, then $b\sim a$.
\item[(E3) Transitive:] If $a\sim b$ and $b\sim c$, then $a\sim c$.
\end{description}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}[Same sign on $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$]
On $A=\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$ define $x\sim y$ if $xy>0$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
There are exactly two equivalence classes: the positive reals and the negative reals.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Difference by a rational number]
On $A=\mathbb{R}$ define $x\sim y$ if $x-y\in \mathbb{Q}$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
The equivalence class of $x$ is $x+\mathbb{Q}=\{x+q:q\in\mathbb{Q}\}$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Same ``direction'' in the plane]
On $A=\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$ define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some non-zero real $\lambda$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
Each equivalence class is a line through the origin with the origin removed.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Equivalent fractions]
Let
\[
A=\{(a,b)\in \mathbb{Z}\times \mathbb{Z} : b\neq 0\}.
\]
Define $(a,b)\sim(c,d)$ if $ad=bc$. Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
Each equivalence class corresponds to a rational number $a/b$; this is one way to construct $\mathbb{Q}$ from $\mathbb{Z}$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{defn}[Equivalence class] \index{equivalence class}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on a set $A$. For $a\in A$, the \textbf{equivalence class} of $a$ is
\[
[a]=\{\, x\in A : x\sim a \,\}.
\]
The set of all equivalence classes is denoted $A/{\sim}$ and is called the \textbf{quotient set}.
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Equivalent elements determine the same class] \label{pro:class_equal}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. If $a\sim b$, then $[a]=[b]$.
Conversely, if $[a]=[b]$, then $a\sim b$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
Assume $a\sim b$. Let $x\in[a]$. Then $x\sim a$, and since $a\sim b$, transitivity gives $x\sim b$, hence $x\in[b]$. So $[a]\subseteq[b]$.
By symmetry, $b\sim a$, and the same argument shows $[b]\subseteq[a]$. Therefore $[a]=[b]$.

Conversely, if $[a]=[b]$, then $a\in[a]$ (by reflexivity), hence $a\in[b]$, so $a\sim b$.
\end{proof}

\begin{pro}[Equivalence classes form a partition] \label{pro:partition} \index{partition}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item For each $a\in A$, we have $a\in [a]$, hence $[a]\neq \emptyset$.
\item For any $a,b\in A$, either $[a]=[b]$ or $[a]\cap[b]=\emptyset$.
\item Every element of $A$ lies in exactly one equivalence class. Equivalently,
\[
A=\bigcup_{a\in A}[a].
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
(1) Reflexivity gives $a\sim a$, hence $a\in[a]$.

(2) Suppose $[a]\cap[b]\neq \emptyset$. Choose $x\in[a]\cap[b]$. Then $x\sim a$ and $x\sim b$.
By symmetry $a\sim x$, hence by transitivity $a\sim b$. Proposition \ref{pro:class_equal} now gives $[a]=[b]$.

(3) By (1), each $a$ lies in $[a]$. By (2), two distinct classes cannot overlap, so each element lies in exactly one class.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Congruences and modular arithmetic}

\begin{defn}[Congruence modulo $n$] \label{defn:congruence} \index{congruence}\index{modular arithmetic}
Let $n$ be a positive integer. For integers $a,b$, we say that \textbf{$a$ is congruent to $b$ modulo $n$}, written
\[
a \equiv b \pmod{n},
\]
if $n$ divides $a-b$, i.e.\ $n\,|\,(a-b)$.
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Congruence is an equivalence relation] \label{pro:cong_equiv}
Fix $n\in\mathbb{N}$. The relation $\equiv \pmod n$ is an equivalence relation on $\mathbb{Z}$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
\emph{Reflexive:} $a-a=0$, so $n|(a-a)$, hence $a\equiv a\pmod n$.

\emph{Symmetric:} if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then $n|(a-b)$, hence $n|-(a-b)=(b-a)$ (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(2)), so $b\equiv a\pmod n$.

\emph{Transitive:} if $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $b\equiv c\pmod n$, then $n|(a-b)$ and $n|(b-c)$, hence
$n|[(a-b)+(b-c)]=(a-c)$ (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10)), so $a\equiv c\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{defn}[Residue class] \index{residue class}
For $a\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $n\in\mathbb{N}$, the \textbf{congruence class} (or \textbf{residue class}) of $a$ modulo $n$ is
\[
[a]_n=\{\, x\in\mathbb{Z} : x\equiv a \pmod n \,\}.
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Description of congruence classes] \label{pro:class_description}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$ and $a\in\mathbb{Z}$. Then
\[
[a]_n=\{\, a+kn : k\in\mathbb{Z}\,\}.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
If $x\in[a]_n$, then $x\equiv a\pmod n$, so $n|(x-a)$ and hence $x-a=kn$ for some $k\in\mathbb{Z}$, i.e.\ $x=a+kn$.
Conversely, if $x=a+kn$, then $x-a=kn$ is divisible by $n$, so $x\equiv a\pmod n$ and $x\in[a]_n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{pro}[Congruence and remainders] \label{pro:cong_remainder}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$, and let $a,b\in\mathbb{Z}$. Write
\[
a=qn+r,\qquad b=q'n+r',
\]
where $0\le r,r'<n$ (these are the remainders given by the Division Algorithm, Theorem \ref{thm2.1}).
Then
\[
a\equiv b\pmod n \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad r=r'.
\]
Equivalently, $a\equiv b\pmod n$ if and only if $a$ and $b$ have the same remainder upon division by $n$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
We have
\[
a-b=(q-q')n+(r-r').
\]
If $r=r'$, then $a-b=(q-q')n$ is divisible by $n$, so $a\equiv b\pmod n$.

Conversely, suppose $a\equiv b\pmod n$, i.e.\ $n|(a-b)$. Then $n|(r-r')$ as well, since
$(a-b)-(q-q')n=r-r'$.
But $-(n-1)\le r-r'\le n-1$, so the only multiple of $n$ in this range is $0$. Hence $r-r'=0$, i.e.\ $r=r'$.
\end{proof}

\begin{thm}[There are exactly $n$ residue classes modulo $n$] \label{thm:n_classes}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. Every integer $a$ is congruent modulo $n$ to a unique integer $r$ with $0\le r<n$. Consequently,
\[
\mathbb{Z}/\!\equiv\pmod n=\{[0]_n,[1]_n,\ldots,[n-1]_n\}.
\]
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
Apply the Division Algorithm (Theorem \ref{thm2.1}) to write $a=qn+r$ with $0\le r<n$. Then $a$ and $r$ have the same remainder upon division by $n$, hence $a\equiv r\pmod n$ by Proposition \ref{pro:cong_remainder}.
Uniqueness of $r$ follows from the uniqueness of the remainder in Theorem \ref{thm2.1}.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

\subsection*{Congruence arithmetic}

\begin{pro}[Compatibility with addition and multiplication] \label{pro:cong_arith}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, then
\[
a+c \equiv b+d \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ac \equiv bd \pmod n.
\]
In particular, if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for every integer $k$,
\[
a+k \equiv b+k \pmod n,\qquad
ka \equiv kb \pmod n.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
From $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, we have $n|(a-b)$ and $n|(c-d)$.

\emph{Addition:} $(a+c)-(b+d)=(a-b)+(c-d)$, so $n$ divides the difference (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10)).

\emph{Multiplication:}
\[
ac-bd=a(c-d)+d(a-b).
\]
Since $n|(c-d)$, we have $n|a(c-d)$ (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(5)); similarly $n|d(a-b)$. Hence $n|(ac-bd)$ by Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10).
The final statements follow by taking $d=c$ or by setting $c=d=k$.
\end{proof}

\begin{cor}[Powers preserve congruence] \label{cor:powers}
If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $m\ge 1$ is an integer, then $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{cor}

\begin{proof}
By Example \ref{ex1.4.8}, $a^m-b^m$ is divisible by $a-b$. Since $n|(a-b)$, it follows that $n|(a^m-b^m)$, i.e.\ $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}
A standard computational principle is now justified:
\[
\text{If } a\equiv r\pmod n,\ \text{then in calculations ``mod $n$'' you may replace $a$ by $r$.}
\]
By Theorem \ref{thm:n_classes}, we may always choose $r$ to be the unique remainder with $0\le r<n$.
\end{rem}

\small
\begin{ex}[A previously proved result in one line]
For $n\ge 1$, show that $3^{2n}+1$ is divisible by $2$ but not by $4$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} Modulo $4$, $3^2=9\equiv 1\pmod 4$, hence $3^{2n}=(3^2)^n\equiv 1\pmod 4$. Therefore
\[
3^{2n}+1 \equiv 1+1 \equiv 2 \pmod 4,
\]
so the number is even but not divisible by $4$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Divisibility via congruence]
Show that $\dfrac{n(n^2+2)}{3}$ is an integer for every integer $n$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} It suffices to show $n(n^2+2)\equiv 0\pmod 3$.
Note that
\[
n^3-n = n(n-1)(n+1)
\]
is a product of three consecutive integers, hence divisible by $3$ (Example \ref{ex1.4.4} with $n=3$). Thus $n^3\equiv n\pmod 3$, and so
\[
n(n^2+2)=n^3+2n \equiv n+2n = 3n \equiv 0 \pmod 3.
\]
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[A quick remainder computation]
Find the remainder of $2^{100}+3^{100}$ upon division by $5$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} Modulo $5$,
\[
2^4=16\equiv 1\pmod 5,\qquad 3^4=81\equiv 1\pmod 5.
\]
Hence $2^{100}\equiv 1$ and $3^{100}\equiv 1$, so
\[
2^{100}+3^{100}\equiv 2\pmod 5.
\]
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\small
\begin{exer} \label{exer:equiv_cong}
~
\begin{enumerate}
\item Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation. Prove that $\operatorname{Dom}(R)\subseteq A$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)\subseteq B$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}$ define $x\,R\,y \iff y=x^2$. Determine $\operatorname{Dom}(R)$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)$.
\item For each of the relations below, determine whether it is reflexive, symmetric, and/or transitive:
\begin{enumerate}
\item On $\mathbb{R}$, define $x\sim y \iff x\le y$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$, define $x\sim y \iff xy>0$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$, define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ iff $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some real $\lambda$ (allowing $\lambda=0$).
\end{enumerate}
\item Show that for any integer $x$, $x^2\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 4$.
\item Show that if $x$ is odd, then $x^2\equiv 1\pmod 8$.
\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $10$.
\item Show that if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for any polynomial $P(t)\in\mathbb{Z}[t]$ (integer coefficients),
\[
P(a)\equiv P(b)\pmod n.
\]
(Hint: build $P$ from additions and multiplications, and use Proposition \ref{pro:cong_arith}.)

\item Prove that for integers $n\ge 2$ and $m\ge 1$,
\[
(n+1)^m \equiv 1 \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
(n-1)^m \equiv (-1)^m \pmod n.
\]
(Hint: Binomial Theorem.)

\item Prove that for every integer $t$, the number $t^5-t$ is divisible by $30$.

\item Prove that for every integer $a$, one has $a^2\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 3$. Deduce that if $a^2+b^2$ is divisible by $3$, then $3|a$ and $3|b$.

\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $100$.

Hint: First compute $7^{2026}\pmod 4$ and $7^{2026}\pmod{25}$, then find the unique integer in $\{0,1,\ldots,99\}$ satisfying both congruences.

\item ({\bf Harder}) Recall that $p$ is \textbf{prime} if its only positive divisors are $1$ and $p$.
Let $p$ be prime. Prove that for $1\le k\le p-1$, the integer $p$ divides $\binom{p}{k}$.
Deduce that for all integers $a,b$,
\[
(a+b)^p \equiv a^p+b^p \pmod p.
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{exer}
\normalsize
% ============================================================
```

```latex
% ============================================================
\newpage
\section{Equivalence Relations, Equivalence Classes, Congruence Arithmetic}

\noindent
In earlier sections we often grouped integers by the \emph{remainder} they leave when divided by a fixed positive integer (for example, ``even vs odd'', or ``cases modulo $3$'').  
This chapter gives a clean language for such grouping: \textbf{equivalence relations}.  
Once we have that language, \textbf{congruence arithmetic} (also called \textbf{modular arithmetic}) becomes a systematic tool rather than repeated casework.

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Relations, domain, and range}

\begin{defn}[Relation] \index{relation}
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets. A \textbf{(binary) relation} $R$ from $A$ to $B$ is any subset
\[
R \subseteq A \times B.
\]
If $(a,b)\in R$, we also write $a\,R\,b$.
If $A=B$, we say $R$ is a relation \textbf{on} $A$.
\end{defn}

\noindent
\textit{Think of a relation as a ``yes/no rule'' for ordered pairs: which pairs $(a,b)$ are allowed, and which are not.}

\begin{defn}[Domain and range] \index{domain of a relation}\index{range of a relation}
Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item The \textbf{domain} of $R$ is the set of all first entries that actually occur in $R$:
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\{\, a\in A \ : \ \exists\, b\in B \text{ with } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\item The \textbf{range} (also called the \textbf{image}) of $R$ is the set of all second entries that actually occur in $R$:
\[
\operatorname{Ran}(R)=\{\, b\in B \ : \ \exists\, a\in A \text{ with } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\end{itemize}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}
Let $R\subseteq \mathbb{R}\times \mathbb{R}$ be defined by $x\,R\,y \iff x^2+y^2=1$. Then
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\operatorname{Ran}(R)=[-1,1].
\]
Indeed, $(x,y)$ satisfies $x^2+y^2=1$ for some real $y$ if and only if $x^2\le 1$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{rem}
A function $f:A\to B$ is a special relation in which \emph{each} $a\in A$ is paired with \emph{exactly one} $b\in B$.
Relations are more flexible: one $a$ may relate to many $b$'s, or to none.
\end{rem}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Equivalence relations: ``belonging to the same group''}

\begin{defn}[Equivalence relation] \index{equivalence relation}\index{reflexive}\index{symmetric}\index{transitive}
Let $A$ be a set and let $\sim$ be a relation on $A$. We say that $\sim$ is an \textbf{equivalence relation} if it satisfies:
\begin{description}
\item[(E1) Reflexive:] $a\sim a$ for all $a\in A$.
\item[(E2) Symmetric:] If $a\sim b$, then $b\sim a$.
\item[(E3) Transitive:] If $a\sim b$ and $b\sim c$, then $a\sim c$.
\end{description}
\end{defn}

\noindent
\textit{Heuristic: an equivalence relation is a precise way of saying ``these two objects should be treated as the same kind''.}
The three properties match common sense:
\[
\text{``same kind as itself''},\quad
\text{``if $a$ matches $b$ then $b$ matches $a$''},\quad
\text{``matching chains together''}.
\]

\small
\begin{ex}[Same sign on $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$]
On $A=\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$ define $x\sim y$ if $xy>0$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation. (It says: $x$ and $y$ have the same sign.)
There are exactly two equivalence classes: the positive reals and the negative reals.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Difference by a rational number]
On $A=\mathbb{R}$ define $x\sim y$ if $x-y\in \mathbb{Q}$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
The equivalence class of $x$ is $x+\mathbb{Q}=\{x+q:q\in\mathbb{Q}\}$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Same direction in the plane]
On $A=\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$ define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some non-zero real $\lambda$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.
Each equivalence class is a line through the origin with the origin removed.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Equivalent fractions]
Let
\[
A=\{(a,b)\in \mathbb{Z}\times \mathbb{Z} : b\neq 0\}.
\]
Define $(a,b)\sim(c,d)$ if $ad=bc$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation: it captures the idea that $a/b$ and $c/d$ represent the same rational number.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{defn}[Equivalence class] \index{equivalence class}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$.
For $a\in A$, the \textbf{equivalence class} of $a$ is
\[
[a]=\{\, x\in A : x\sim a \,\}.
\]
The set of all equivalence classes is denoted $A/{\sim}$ and is called the \textbf{quotient set}.
\end{defn}

\noindent
So $[a]$ is the ``group'' containing $a$: all elements of $A$ that are equivalent to $a$.

\begin{pro}[Same class $\Longleftrightarrow$ equivalent] \label{pro:class_equal}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. For $a,b\in A$,
\[
a\sim b \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad [a]=[b].
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
($\Rightarrow$) Assume $a\sim b$.  
Take any $x\in[a]$. Then $x\sim a$, and since $a\sim b$, transitivity gives $x\sim b$. Hence $x\in[b]$, so $[a]\subseteq[b]$.
By symmetry, $b\sim a$, so the same argument gives $[b]\subseteq[a]$. Thus $[a]=[b]$.

($\Leftarrow$) If $[a]=[b]$, then $a\in[a]$ by reflexivity, hence $a\in[b]$, which means $a\sim b$.
\end{proof}

\begin{pro}[Equivalence classes partition the set] \label{pro:partition} \index{partition}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Each equivalence class is non-empty.
\item Any two equivalence classes are either identical or disjoint.
\item Every element of $A$ lies in exactly one equivalence class, so
\[
A=\bigcup_{a\in A}[a].
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
(1) For any $a\in A$, reflexivity gives $a\in[a]$.

(2) Suppose $[a]\cap[b]\neq\emptyset$. Pick $x\in[a]\cap[b]$.
Then $x\sim a$ and $x\sim b$. By symmetry $a\sim x$, and by transitivity $a\sim b$.
Proposition \ref{pro:class_equal} then gives $[a]=[b]$.

(3) By (1), each $a\in A$ lies in $[a]$, so the union covers $A$.
By (2), two different classes cannot overlap, so no element can lie in two different classes.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Congruence modulo $n$: the equivalence relation of ``same remainder''}

\begin{defn}[Congruence modulo $n$] \label{defn:congruence} \index{congruence}\index{modular arithmetic}
Let $n$ be a positive integer. For integers $a,b$, we say that \textbf{$a$ is congruent to $b$ modulo $n$}, written
\[
a \equiv b \pmod{n},
\]
if $n$ divides $a-b$, i.e.\ $n\,|\,(a-b)$.
\end{defn}

\noindent
This definition is extremely useful because it connects immediately to remainders:

\begin{pro}[Congruence and remainders] \label{pro:cong_remainder}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$, and let $a,b\in\mathbb{Z}$. Write
\[
a=qn+r,\qquad b=q'n+r',
\]
where $0\le r,r'<n$ (these are the remainders from the Division Algorithm, Theorem \ref{thm2.1}).
Then
\[
a\equiv b\pmod n \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad r=r'.
\]
In words: $a\equiv b\pmod n$ if and only if $a$ and $b$ have the same remainder upon division by $n$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
Subtract:
\[
a-b=(q-q')n+(r-r').
\]
If $r=r'$, then $a-b=(q-q')n$ is divisible by $n$, so $a\equiv b\pmod n$.

Conversely, suppose $a\equiv b\pmod n$, so $n|(a-b)$.
Then $n|(r-r')$ because $(a-b)-(q-q')n=r-r'$.
But $-(n-1)\le r-r'\le n-1$, so the only multiple of $n$ in this range is $0$.
Hence $r-r'=0$, i.e.\ $r=r'$.
\end{proof}

\begin{pro}[Congruence is an equivalence relation] \label{pro:cong_equiv}
Fix $n\in\mathbb{N}$. The relation $\equiv \pmod n$ is an equivalence relation on $\mathbb{Z}$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
Using Proposition \ref{pro:cong_remainder}: two integers are congruent modulo $n$ exactly when they have the same remainder upon division by $n$.
\begin{itemize}
\item Reflexive: every integer has the same remainder as itself.
\item Symmetric: if $a$ has the same remainder as $b$, then $b$ has the same remainder as $a$.
\item Transitive: if $a$ has the same remainder as $b$, and $b$ has the same remainder as $c$, then $a$ has the same remainder as $c$.
\end{itemize}
Therefore $\equiv\pmod n$ is an equivalence relation.
\end{proof}

\begin{defn}[Residue class] \index{residue class}
For $a\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $n\in\mathbb{N}$, the \textbf{residue class} of $a$ modulo $n$ is
\[
[a]_n=\{\, x\in\mathbb{Z} : x\equiv a \pmod n \,\}.
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[What the class $[a]_n$ looks like] \label{pro:class_description}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$ and $a\in\mathbb{Z}$. Then
\[
[a]_n=\{\, a+kn : k\in\mathbb{Z}\,\}.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
$x\equiv a\pmod n$ means $n|(x-a)$, i.e.\ $x-a=kn$ for some $k\in\mathbb{Z}$, hence $x=a+kn$.
The converse is immediate.
\end{proof}

\begin{thm}[Exactly $n$ residue classes modulo $n$] \label{thm:n_classes}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. Every integer $a$ is congruent modulo $n$ to a unique integer $r$ with $0\le r<n$.
Consequently,
\[
\mathbb{Z}/\!\equiv\pmod n=\{[0]_n,[1]_n,\ldots,[n-1]_n\}.
\]
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
By Theorem \ref{thm2.1}, write $a=qn+r$ with $0\le r<n$.
Then $a$ and $r$ have the same remainder upon division by $n$, so $a\equiv r\pmod n$ by Proposition \ref{pro:cong_remainder}.
Uniqueness of $r$ is exactly the uniqueness of the remainder in Theorem \ref{thm2.1}.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Congruence arithmetic (how to compute efficiently)}

\begin{pro}[Adding and multiplying congruences] \label{pro:cong_arith}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$. If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, then
\[
a+c \equiv b+d \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ac \equiv bd \pmod n.
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
From $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$ we have $n|(a-b)$ and $n|(c-d)$.

\emph{Addition:}
\[
(a+c)-(b+d)=(a-b)+(c-d),
\]
so $n$ divides the difference (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10)).

\emph{Multiplication:}
\[
ac-bd=a(c-d)+d(a-b).
\]
Since $n|(c-d)$, we have $n|a(c-d)$ (Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(5)), and similarly $n|d(a-b)$.
Thus $n|(ac-bd)$ by Proposition \ref{pro1.4.2}(10).
\end{proof}

\begin{cor}[Subtraction and powers] \label{cor:sub_powers}
If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, then $a-c\equiv b-d\pmod n$.
Also, if $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $m\ge 1$, then $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{cor}

\begin{proof}
Subtraction follows from addition by rewriting $a-c=a+(-c)$ and $b-d=b+(-d)$.

For powers, by Example \ref{ex1.4.8}, $a^m-b^m$ is divisible by $a-b$.
Since $n|(a-b)$, it follows that $n|(a^m-b^m)$, i.e.\ $a^m\equiv b^m\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}[The standard workflow] \index{modular arithmetic!workflow}
To compute a large expression ``mod $n$'':
\begin{enumerate}
\item Replace each integer by its remainder in $\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\}$.
\item Simplify using ordinary algebra, but \emph{every time numbers get large}, reduce again.
\item Use Proposition \ref{pro:cong_arith} and Corollary \ref{cor:sub_powers} to justify each replacement.
\end{enumerate}
\end{rem}

\small
\begin{ex}[A previously proved result in one line]
For $n\ge 1$, show that $3^{2n}+1$ is divisible by $2$ but not by $4$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} Modulo $4$, $3^2=9\equiv 1\pmod 4$, hence $3^{2n}=(3^2)^n\equiv 1\pmod 4$.
Thus
\[
3^{2n}+1 \equiv 1+1 \equiv 2 \pmod 4,
\]
so it is even but not divisible by $4$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Divisibility via congruence]
Show that $\dfrac{n(n^2+2)}{3}$ is an integer for every integer $n$.

\smallskip
\noindent
{\bf Solution.} It suffices to show $n(n^2+2)\equiv 0\pmod 3$.
Note that $n^3-n=n(n-1)(n+1)$ is a product of three consecutive integers, hence divisible by $3$ (Example \ref{ex1.4.4} with $n=3$).
So $n^3\equiv n\pmod 3$, and
\[
n(n^2+2)=n^3+2n \equiv n+2n = 3n \equiv 0 \pmod 3.
\]
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\small
\begin{exer} \label{exer:equiv_cong}
~
\begin{enumerate}
% --- Relations / equivalence relations ---
\item Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation. Prove that $\operatorname{Dom}(R)\subseteq A$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)\subseteq B$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}$ define $x\,R\,y \iff y=x^2$. Determine $\operatorname{Dom}(R)$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)$.
\item For each of the relations below, determine whether it is reflexive, symmetric, and/or transitive:
\begin{enumerate}
\item On $\mathbb{R}$, define $x\sim y \iff x\le y$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$, define $x\sim y \iff xy>0$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$, define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ iff $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some real $\lambda$ (allowing $\lambda=0$).
\end{enumerate}

\item Define $x\sim y$ on $\mathbb{R}$ by $\lfloor x\rfloor=\lfloor y\rfloor$.
Show that $\sim$ is an equivalence relation and describe the equivalence class of a real number $x$.

\item Define $x\sim y$ on $\mathbb{R}$ by $x-y\in\mathbb{Z}$.
Show that $\sim$ is an equivalence relation. Describe the quotient set $\mathbb{R}/\!\sim$ in a concrete way (hint: fractional part).

% --- Basic congruences ---
\item Show that for any integer $x$, $x^2\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 4$.
\item Show that if $x$ is odd, then $x^2\equiv 1\pmod 8$. Deduce that if $x$ is odd, then $x^4\equiv 1\pmod{16}$.
\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $10$.
\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $100$.

\item Prove that for integers $n\ge 2$ and $m\ge 1$,
\[
(n+1)^m \equiv 1 \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
(n-1)^m \equiv (-1)^m \pmod n.
\]
(Hint: Binomial Theorem.)

\item Prove that for every integer $t$, the number $t^5-t$ is divisible by $30$.

\item Prove that for every integer $a$, one has $a^2\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 3$.
Deduce that if $a^2+b^2$ is divisible by $3$, then $3|a$ and $3|b$.

\item Solve the congruence $7x\equiv 3\pmod{20}$ and give all solutions $x\in\mathbb{Z}$.

\item Show that if $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for any polynomial $P(t)\in\mathbb{Z}[t]$,
\[
P(a)\equiv P(b)\pmod n.
\]
(Hint: build $P$ using addition and multiplication, and use Proposition \ref{pro:cong_arith}.)

\item Prove that among any $n$ consecutive integers, for each $r\in\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\}$ there is \emph{exactly one} integer congruent to $r$ modulo $n$.

% --- Higher difficulty congruence problems ---
\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $1000$.

Hint: First compute $7^{2026}\pmod 8$ and $7^{2026}\pmod{125}$, then find the unique integer in $\{0,1,\ldots,999\}$ satisfying both congruences.

\item Let $p$ be an odd prime. Show that
\[
1^2+2^2+\cdots+(p-1)^2 \equiv 0 \pmod p.
\]
(One approach: use the known formula for $\sum_{k=1}^{n}k^2$.)

\item ({\bf Harder}) Let $p$ be prime. Prove that for $1\le k\le p-1$, the integer $p$ divides $\binom{p}{k}$.
Deduce that for all integers $a,b$,
\[
(a+b)^p \equiv a^p+b^p \pmod p.
\]

\item ({\bf Harder}) (\textbf{Fermat's Little Theorem}) Let $p$ be prime. Prove that for every integer $a$,
\[
a^p \equiv a \pmod p.
\]
(Hint: Use the previous exercise to show $(a+1)^p\equiv a^p+1\pmod p$ and then use induction on $a\ge 0$. Extend to negative $a$.)

\item ({\bf Very Hard}) Prove that for every integer $t$, the number $t^7-t$ is divisible by $42$.

Hint: Show divisibility by $2$ and $3$ using small-modulus arguments, and divisibility by $7$ using Fermat's Little Theorem.
\end{enumerate}
\end{exer}
\normalsize
```

## 4.2 Basic Properties of Congruence

In the first chapter of *Disquisitiones Arithmeticae*, Gauss introduces the concept of congruence and the notation that makes it such a powerful technique (he explains that he was induced to adopt the symbol $\equiv$ because of the close analogy with algebraic equality). According to Gauss, "If a number $n$ measures the difference between two numbers $a$ and $b$, then $a$ and $b$ are said to be congruent with respect to $n$; if not, incongruent." Putting this into the form of a definition, we have Definition 4.1.

---

**Definition 4.1.** Let $n$ be a fixed positive integer. Two integers $a$ and $b$ are said to be **congruent modulo** $n$, symbolized by
$$a \equiv b \pmod{n}$$
if $n$ divides the difference $a - b$; that is, provided that $a - b = kn$ for some integer $k$.

---

To fix the idea, consider $n = 7$. It is routine to check that
$$3 \equiv 24 \pmod{7}, \quad -31 \equiv 11 \pmod{7}, \quad -15 \equiv -64 \pmod{7}$$
because $3 - 24 = (-3)7$, $-31 - 11 = (-6)7$, and $-15 - (-64) = 7 \cdot 7$. When $n \nmid (a - b)$, we say that $a$ is **incongruent to** $b$ **modulo** $n$, and in this case we write $a \not\equiv b \pmod{n}$. For a simple example: $25 \not\equiv 12 \pmod{7}$, because $7$ fails to divide $25 - 12 = 13$.

It is to be noted that any two integers are congruent modulo $1$, whereas two integers are congruent modulo $2$ when they are both even or both odd. Inasmuch as congruence modulo $1$ is not particularly interesting, the usual practice is to assume that $n > 1$.

Given an integer $a$, let $q$ and $r$ be its quotient and remainder upon division by $n$, so that
$$a = qn + r, \qquad 0 \leq r < n$$
Then, by definition of congruence, $a \equiv r \pmod{n}$. Because there are $n$ choices for $r$, we see that every integer is congruent modulo $n$ to exactly one of the values $0, 1, \ldots, n-1$; in particular, $a \equiv 0 \pmod{n}$ if and only if $n \mid a$. The set of $n$ integers $0, 1, \ldots, n-1$ is called the set of **least nonnegative residues modulo** $n$.

In general, a collection of $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ is said to form a **complete set of residues** (or a **complete system of residues**) **modulo** $n$ if every integer is congruent modulo $n$ to one and only one of the $a_i$. To put it another way, $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ are congruent modulo $n$ to $0, 1, \ldots, n-1$, taken in some order. For instance,
$$-12, -4, 11, 13, 22, 62, 71$$
constitute a complete set of residues modulo $7$; here, we have
$$-12 \equiv 2, \quad -4 \equiv 3, \quad 11 \equiv 4, \quad 13 \equiv 6, \quad 22 \equiv 1, \quad 62 \equiv 6, \quad 71 \equiv 0$$
all modulo $7$. An observation of some importance is that any $n$ integers form a complete set of residues modulo $n$ if and only if no two of the integers are congruent modulo $n$. We shall need this fact later.

Our first theorem provides a useful characterization of congruence modulo $n$ in terms of remainders upon division by $n$.

---

**Theorem 4.1.** For arbitrary integers $a$ and $b$, $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ if and only if $a$ and $b$ leave the same nonnegative remainder when divided by $n$.

*Proof.* First take $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, so that $a - b = kn$ for some integer $k$. Upon division by $n$, $b$ leaves a certain remainder $r$; that is, $b = qn + r$, where $0 \leq r < n$. Therefore,
$$a = b + kn = (qn + r) + kn = (q + k)n + r$$
which indicates that $a$ has the same remainder as $b$.

On the other hand, suppose we can write $a = q_1 n + r$ and $b = q_2 n + r$, with the same remainder $r$ $(0 \leq r < n)$. Then
$$a - b = (q_1 n + r) - (q_2 n + r) = (q_1 - q_2)n$$
whence $n \mid a - b$. In the language of congruences, we have $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$.

---

**Example 4.1.** Because the integers $-56$ and $-11$ can be expressed in the form
$$-56 = (-7)8 + 0, \qquad -11 = (-2)8 + 5$$
with the same remainder $5$, Theorem 4.1 tells us that $-56 \equiv -11 \pmod{8}$. Going in the other direction, the congruence $-31 \equiv 11 \pmod{7}$ implies that $-31$ and $11$ have the same remainder when divided by $7$; this is clear from the relations
$$-31 = (-5)7 + 4, \qquad 11 = 1 \cdot 7 + 4$$

---

Congruence may be viewed as a generalized form of equality, in the sense that its behavior with respect to addition and multiplication is reminiscent of ordinary equality. Some of the elementary properties of equality that carry over to congruences appear in the next theorem.

---

**Theorem 4.2.** Let $n > 1$ be fixed and $a$, $b$, $c$, $d$ be arbitrary integers. Then the following properties hold:

**(a)** $a \equiv a \pmod{n}$.

**(b)** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, then $b \equiv a \pmod{n}$.

**(c)** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $b \equiv c \pmod{n}$, then $a \equiv c \pmod{n}$.

**(d)** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $c \equiv d \pmod{n}$, then $a + c \equiv b + d \pmod{n}$ and $ac \equiv bd \pmod{n}$.

**(e)** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, then $a + c \equiv b + c \pmod{n}$ and $ac \equiv bc \pmod{n}$.

**(f)** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, then $a^k \equiv b^k \pmod{n}$ for any positive integer $k$.

*Proof.* For any integer $a$, we have $a - a = 0 \cdot n$, so that $a \equiv a \pmod{n}$. Now if $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, then $a - b = kn$ for some integer $k$. Hence, $b - a = -(kn) = (-k)n$ and because $-k$ is an integer, this yields property (b).

Property (c) is slightly less obvious: Suppose that $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and also $b \equiv c \pmod{n}$. Then there exist integers $s$ and $k$ satisfying $a - b = sn$ and $b - c = kn$. It follows that
$$a - c = (a - b) + (b - c) = sn + kn = (s + k)n$$
which is $a \equiv c \pmod{n}$ in congruence notation.

In the same vein, if $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $c \equiv d \pmod{n}$, then we are assured that $a - b = k_1 n$ and $c - d = k_2 n$ for some choice of $k_1$ and $k_2$. Adding these equations, we obtain
$$(a + c) - (b + d) = (a - b) + (c - d) = k_1 n + k_2 n = (k_1 + k_2)n$$
or, as a congruence statement, $a + c \equiv b + d \pmod{n}$. As regards the second assertion of property (d), note that
$$ac = (b + k_1 n)(d + k_2 n) = bd + (bk_2 + dk_1 + k_1 k_2 n)n$$
Because $bk_2 + dk_1 + k_1 k_2 n$ is an integer, this says that $ac - bd$ is divisible by $n$, whence $ac \equiv bd \pmod{n}$.

The proof of property (e) is covered by (d) and the fact that $c \equiv c \pmod{n}$. Finally, we obtain property (f) by making an induction argument. The statement certainly holds for $k = 1$, and we will assume it is true for some fixed $k$. From (d), we know that $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $a^k \equiv b^k \pmod{n}$ together imply that $aa^k \equiv bb^k \pmod{n}$, or equivalently $a^{k+1} \equiv b^{k+1} \pmod{n}$. This is the form the statement should take for $k+1$, and so the induction step is complete.

---

Before going further, we should illustrate that congruences can be a great help in carrying out certain types of computations.

**Example 4.2.** Let us endeavor to show that $31$ divides $2^{20} - 1$. We begin by noting that $2^5 \equiv -1 \pmod{31}$, whence $(2^5)^4 \equiv (-1)^4 \pmod{31}$ by Theorem 4.2(f); in other words, $2^{20} \equiv 1 \cdot 1 \pmod{31}$. But $1 \equiv -1 \pmod{31}$, and so $1 \cdot 1 \equiv 1 \pmod{31}$. Using parts (b) and (e) of Theorem 4.2, we finally arrive at
$$2^{20} - 1 \equiv 1 \cdot 1 - 1 \equiv 1 - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{31}$$
Thus, $31 \mid 2^{20} - 1$, as desired.

---

**Example 4.3.** For another example in the same spirit, suppose that we are asked to find the remainder obtained upon dividing the sum
$$1! + 2! + 3! + 4! + \cdots + 99! + 100!$$
by $12$. Without the aid of congruences this would be an awesome calculation. The observation that starts us off is that $4! \equiv 24 \equiv 0 \pmod{12}$; thus, for $k \geq 4$,
$$k! \equiv 4! \cdot 5 \cdot 6 \cdots k \equiv 0 \cdot 5 \cdot 6 \cdots k \equiv 0 \pmod{12}$$
In this way, we find that
$$1! + 2! + 3! + 4! + \cdots + 100! \equiv 1! + 2! + 3! + 0 + \cdots + 0 \equiv 9 \pmod{12}$$
Accordingly, the sum in question leaves a remainder of $9$ when divided by $12$.

---

In Theorem 4.2 we saw that if $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, then $ca \equiv cb \pmod{n}$ for any integer $c$. The converse, however, fails to hold. As an example, perhaps as simple as any, note that $2 \cdot 4 \equiv 2 \cdot 1 \pmod{6}$, whereas $4 \not\equiv 1 \pmod{6}$. In brief: One cannot unrestrictedly cancel a common factor in the arithmetic of congruences.

With suitable precautions, cancellation can be allowed; one step in this direction, and an important one, is provided by the following theorem.

---

**Theorem 4.3.** If $ca \equiv cb \pmod{n}$, then $a \equiv b \pmod{n/d}$, where $d = \gcd(c, n)$.

*Proof.* By hypothesis, we can write
$$c(a - b) = ca - cb = kn$$
for some integer $k$. Knowing that $\gcd(c, n) = d$, there exist relatively prime integers $r$ and $s$ satisfying $c = dr$, $n = ds$. When these values are substituted in the displayed equation and the common factor $d$ canceled, the net result is
$$r(a - b) = ks$$
Hence, $s \mid r(a - b)$ and $\gcd(r, s) = 1$. Euclid's lemma yields $s \mid a - b$, which may be recast as $a \equiv b \pmod{s}$; in other words, $a \equiv b \pmod{n/d}$.

---

Theorem 4.3 gets its maximum force when the requirement that $\gcd(c, n) = 1$ is added, for then the cancellation may be accomplished without a change in modulus.

**Corollary 1.** If $ca \equiv cb \pmod{n}$ and $\gcd(c, n) = 1$, then $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$.

We take a moment to record a special case of Corollary 1 that we shall have frequent occasion to use, namely, Corollary 2.

**Corollary 2.** If $ca \equiv cb \pmod{p}$ and $p \nmid c$, where $p$ is a prime number, then $a \equiv b \pmod{p}$.

*Proof.* The conditions $p \nmid c$ and $p$ a prime imply that $\gcd(c, p) = 1$.

---

**Example 4.4.** Consider the congruence $33 \equiv 15 \pmod{9}$ or, if one prefers, $3 \cdot 11 \equiv 3 \cdot 5 \pmod{9}$. Because $\gcd(3, 9) = 3$, Theorem 4.3 leads to the conclusion that $11 \equiv 5 \pmod{3}$. A further illustration is given by the congruence $-35 \equiv 45 \pmod{8}$, which is the same as $5 \cdot (-7) \equiv 5 \cdot 9 \pmod{8}$. The integers $5$ and $8$ being relatively prime, we may cancel the factor $5$ to obtain a correct congruence $-7 \equiv 9 \pmod{8}$.

Let us call attention to the fact that, in Theorem 4.3, it is unnecessary to stipulate that $c \not\equiv 0 \pmod{n}$. Indeed, if $c \equiv 0 \pmod{n}$, then $\gcd(c, n) = n$ and the conclusion of the theorem would state that $a \equiv b \pmod{1}$; but, as we remarked earlier, this holds trivially for all integers $a$ and $b$.

There is another curious situation that can arise with congruences: The product of two integers, neither of which is congruent to zero, may turn out to be congruent to zero. For instance, $4 \cdot 3 \equiv 0 \pmod{12}$, but $4 \not\equiv 0 \pmod{12}$ and $3 \not\equiv 0 \pmod{12}$. It is a simple matter to show that if $ab \equiv 0 \pmod{n}$ and $\gcd(a, n) = 1$, then $b \equiv 0 \pmod{n}$: Corollary 1 permits us legitimately to cancel the factor $a$ from both sides of the congruence $ab \equiv a \cdot 0 \pmod{n}$. A variation on this is that when $ab \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$, with $p$ a prime, then either $a \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$ or $b \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$.

---

## Problems 4.2

**1.** Prove each of the following assertions:

(a) If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $m \mid n$, then $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$.

(b) If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and $c > 0$, then $ca \equiv cb \pmod{cn}$.

(c) If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$ and the integers $a$, $b$, $n$ are all divisible by $d > 0$, then $a/d \equiv b/d \pmod{n/d}$.

**2.** Give an example to show that $a^2 \equiv b^2 \pmod{n}$ need not imply that $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$.

**3.** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, prove that $\gcd(a, n) = \gcd(b, n)$.

**4.** (a) Find the remainders when $250$ and $4179$ are divided by $7$.

(b) What is the remainder when the following sum is divided by $4$?
$$1^5 + 2^5 + 3^5 + \cdots + 99^5 + 100^5$$

**5.** Prove that the integer $53^{103} + 10^{353}$ is divisible by $39$, and that $111333 + 333111$ is divisible by $7$.

**6.** For $k \geq 1$, use congruence theory to establish each of the following divisibility statements:

(a) $7 \mid 5^{2k} + 3 \cdot 2^{5k-2}$

(b) $13 \mid 3^{k+2} + 4^{2k+1}$

(c) $27 \mid 2^{5k+1} + 5^{k+2}$

(d) $43 \mid 6^{k+2} + 7^{2k+1}$

**7.** For $k \geq 1$, show that
$$(-13)^k + 1 \equiv (-13)^k \cdot (-13)^{k-1} \pmod{181}$$
[*Hint:* Notice that $(-13)^2 \equiv -13 + 1 \pmod{181}$; use induction on $k$.]

**8.** Prove the assertions below:

(a) If $a$ is an odd integer, then $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.

(b) For any integer $a$, $a^3 \equiv 0$, $1$, or $6 \pmod{7}$.

(c) For any integer $a$, $a^4 \equiv 0$ or $1 \pmod{5}$.

(d) If the integer $a$ is not divisible by $2$ or $3$, then $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{24}$.

**9.** If $p$ is a prime satisfying $n < p < 2n$, show that
$$\binom{2n}{n} \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$$

**10.** If $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ is a complete set of residues modulo $n$ and $\gcd(a, n) = 1$, prove that $aa_1, aa_2, \ldots, aa_n$ is also a complete set of residues modulo $n$.
[*Hint:* It suffices to show that the numbers in question are incongruent modulo $n$.]

**11.** Verify that $0$, $2$, $2^2$, $2^3$, $\ldots$, $2^9$ form a complete set of residues modulo $11$, but that $0$, $1^2$, $2^2$, $3^2$, $\ldots$, $10^2$ do not.

**12.** Prove the following statements:

(a) If $\gcd(a, n) = 1$, then the integers
$$c, c + a, c + 2a, c + 3a, \ldots, c + (n-1)a$$
form a complete set of residues modulo $n$ for any $c$.

(b) Any $n$ consecutive integers form a complete set of residues modulo $n$.
[*Hint:* Use part (a).]

(c) The product of any set of $n$ consecutive integers is divisible by $n$.

**13.** Verify that if $a \equiv b \pmod{n_1}$ and $a \equiv b \pmod{n_2}$, then $a \equiv b \pmod{n}$, where the integer $n = \text{lcm}(n_1, n_2)$. Hence, whenever $n_1$ and $n_2$ are relatively prime, $a \equiv b \pmod{n_1 n_2}$.

**14.** Give an example to show that $a^k \equiv b^k \pmod{n}$ and $k \equiv j \pmod{n}$ need not imply that $a^j \equiv b^j \pmod{n}$.

**15.** Establish that if $a$ is an odd integer, then for any $k \geq 1$
$$a^{2^k} \equiv 1 \pmod{2^{k+2}}$$
[*Hint:* Proceed by induction on $k$.]

**16.** Use the theory of congruences to verify that
$$89 \mid 2^{44} - 1 \quad \text{and} \quad 97 \mid 2^{48} - 1$$

**17.** Prove that whenever $ab \equiv cd \pmod{n}$ and $b \equiv d \pmod{n}$, with $\gcd(b, n) = 1$, then $a \equiv c \pmod{n}$.

**18.** If $a \equiv b \pmod{n_1}$ and $a \equiv c \pmod{n_2}$, prove that $b \equiv c \pmod{n}$, where the integer $n = \gcd(n_1, n_2)$.

metadata.reasoning_title: Integrating Burton's material and refining concepts

content.text:
bash -lc python - <<'PY'
import fitz, os
pdf_path='/mnt/data/congience_arithmetic_david_burton_elementary_number_theory.pdf'
doc=fitz.open(pdf_path)
out_dir='/mnt/data/burton_pages'
os.makedirs(out_dir, exist_ok=True)
zoom=2.5  # ~180-200 dpi
mat=fitz.Matrix(zoom, zoom)
for i in range(len(doc)):
    page=doc.load_page(i)
    pix=page.get_pixmap(matrix=mat, alpha=False)
    out=os.path.join(out_dir, f'page_{i+1}.png')
    pix.save(out)
print('pages', len(doc), 'saved to', out_dir)
PY

I’ll also cite examples 4.2 and 4.3 (lines 133-151) and the cancellation theorem (lines 153-166) to maintain accuracy in the response.

thoughts.summary: Updating LaTeX exposition with Burton’s examples
thoughts.content: The mclick lines 47-52 mention congruence and maybe refer to incongruent notation, though I’m not sure it’s clear. I’ll cite those lines and keep citations outside the code block. Next, I’ll craft a high-school-friendly LaTeX exposition, integrating Burton’s examples while avoiding repetition, particularly for factorial sums. Our existing examples will stay.

thoughts.content: Our earlier exposition included relation/equivalence classes, while Burton's was strictly congruence. I'll integrate congruence details from Burton, keeping the relation section but without emphasizing it too much. I'll update exercises, including Burton’s (excluding gcd/lcm dependencies) and adding more challenging ones, like the prime binomial exercise, while removing outdated ones like the mod1000 and mod8 problems.

I also merged in Burton’s **Problems 4.2** that do **not** depend on gcd/lcm, and added additional harder ones (still avoiding gcd/lcm dependence). fileciteturn2file0L193-L206 fileciteturn2file0L209-L222

```latex
% ============================================================
\newpage
\section{Equivalence Relations, Equivalence Classes, Congruence Arithmetic}

\noindent
Earlier, we repeatedly grouped integers by the \emph{remainder} they leave when divided by a fixed positive integer (for example, splitting into cases ``mod $3$'').  
This chapter makes that idea systematic. We first introduce \textbf{equivalence relations} (a general way to say ``belong to the same group''), and then focus on the most important equivalence relation in number theory: \textbf{congruence modulo $n$}.

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Relations, domain, and range}

\begin{defn}[Relation] \index{relation}
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets. A \textbf{(binary) relation} $R$ from $A$ to $B$ is any subset
\[
R \subseteq A \times B.
\]
If $(a,b)\in R$, we also write $a\,R\,b$.
If $A=B$, we say $R$ is a relation \textbf{on} $A$.
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}[Domain and range] \index{domain of a relation}\index{range of a relation}
Let $R\subseteq A\times B$ be a relation.
\begin{itemize}
\item The \textbf{domain} of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\{\, a\in A : \exists\, b\in B \text{ with } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\item The \textbf{range} (also called the \textbf{image}) of $R$ is
\[
\operatorname{Ran}(R)=\{\, b\in B : \exists\, a\in A \text{ with } (a,b)\in R \,\}.
\]
\end{itemize}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}
Let $R\subseteq \mathbb{R}\times \mathbb{R}$ be defined by $x\,R\,y \iff x^2+y^2=1$. Then
\[
\operatorname{Dom}(R)=\operatorname{Ran}(R)=[-1,1].
\]
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Equivalence relations and equivalence classes}

\begin{defn}[Equivalence relation] \index{equivalence relation}\index{reflexive}\index{symmetric}\index{transitive}
Let $A$ be a set and let $\sim$ be a relation on $A$. We say that $\sim$ is an \textbf{equivalence relation} if:
\begin{description}
\item[(E1) Reflexive:] $a\sim a$ for all $a\in A$.
\item[(E2) Symmetric:] If $a\sim b$, then $b\sim a$.
\item[(E3) Transitive:] If $a\sim b$ and $b\sim c$, then $a\sim c$.
\end{description}
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}[Same sign]
On $A=\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$ define $x\sim y$ if $xy>0$. This is an equivalence relation.
There are exactly two equivalence classes: positives and negatives.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Difference by a rational number]
On $A=\mathbb{R}$ define $x\sim y$ if $x-y\in \mathbb{Q}$. This is an equivalence relation.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[Same direction]
On $A=\mathbb{R}^2\setminus\{(0,0)\}$ define $\mathbf{u}\sim \mathbf{v}$ if $\mathbf{u}=\lambda \mathbf{v}$ for some non-zero real $\lambda$.
This is an equivalence relation.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{defn}[Equivalence class] \index{equivalence class}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. For $a\in A$, the \textbf{equivalence class} of $a$ is
\[
[a]=\{\, x\in A : x\sim a \,\}.
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{pro}[Same class $\Longleftrightarrow$ equivalent] \label{pro:class_equal}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. For $a,b\in A$,
\[
a\sim b \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad [a]=[b].
\]
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
($\Rightarrow$) Assume $a\sim b$. Take $x\in[a]$, so $x\sim a$. Then $x\sim b$ by transitivity, hence $x\in[b]$.
Thus $[a]\subseteq[b]$. By symmetry, $[b]\subseteq[a]$, so $[a]=[b]$.

($\Leftarrow$) If $[a]=[b]$, then $a\in[a]$ (reflexive), so $a\in[b]$, i.e.\ $a\sim b$.
\end{proof}

\begin{pro}[Equivalence classes partition the set] \label{pro:partition} \index{partition}
Let $\sim$ be an equivalence relation on $A$. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Each class $[a]$ is non-empty.
\item Any two classes are either identical or disjoint.
\item Every element of $A$ lies in exactly one class.
\end{enumerate}
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
(1) $a\in[a]$ by reflexivity.

(2) If $[a]\cap[b]\neq\emptyset$, pick $x$ in the intersection. Then $x\sim a$ and $x\sim b$.
So $a\sim b$, hence $[a]=[b]$ by Proposition \ref{pro:class_equal}.

(3) Each $a$ lies in $[a]$, and (2) prevents overlap.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Congruence modulo $n$}

\noindent
Congruence was popularized by Gauss as a powerful replacement for ``remainder casework''.
It behaves much like equality, but \emph{up to a fixed modulus}.

\begin{defn}[Congruent; incongruent] \label{defn:congruence} \index{congruence}\index{incongruent}
Fix a positive integer $n$. For integers $a,b$, we say that $a$ and $b$ are \textbf{congruent modulo $n$}, written
\[
a \equiv b \pmod n,
\]
if $n$ divides $a-b$, i.e.\ if $a-b=kn$ for some integer $k$.
If $n\nmid(a-b)$, we say $a$ is \textbf{incongruent} to $b$ modulo $n$, and write
\[
a \not\equiv b \pmod n.
\]
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}[Quick checks modulo $7$]
\[
3\equiv 24 \pmod 7,\qquad -31\equiv 11 \pmod 7,\qquad -15\equiv -64 \pmod 7,
\]
since the differences are multiples of $7$. But $25\not\equiv 12\pmod 7$ because $25-12=13$ is not divisible by $7$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{rem}
Any two integers are congruent modulo $1$. Congruence modulo $2$ is exactly ``same parity'' (both even or both odd).
Since modulo $1$ is trivial, we usually assume $n>1$ unless stated otherwise.
\end{rem}

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Least nonnegative residues and complete residue systems}

\begin{pro}[Least nonnegative residue] \label{pro:least_residue} \index{least nonnegative residue}
Let $n\in\mathbb{N}$ with $n>1$, and let $a\in\mathbb{Z}$. There exists a unique integer $r$ such that
\[
0\le r<n \quad\text{and}\quad a\equiv r\pmod n.
\]
The integer $r$ is called the \textbf{least nonnegative residue} of $a$ modulo $n$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
By the Division Algorithm (Theorem \ref{thm2.1}), there exist unique integers $q,r$ such that
\[
a=qn+r,\qquad 0\le r<n.
\]
Then $a-r=qn$ is divisible by $n$, so $a\equiv r\pmod n$. Uniqueness of $r$ is the uniqueness of the remainder.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}
The set $\{0,1,2,\ldots,n-1\}$ is called the set of \textbf{least nonnegative residues modulo $n$}.
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}[Complete residue system] \index{complete residue system}\index{complete set of residues}
A list of $n$ integers $a_1,a_2,\ldots,a_n$ is called a \textbf{complete residue system modulo $n$}
if every integer is congruent modulo $n$ to \emph{exactly one} of the $a_i$.
Equivalently, $\{a_1,\ldots,a_n\}$ hits each of the residue classes $0,1,\ldots,n-1$ once (in some order).
\end{defn}

\small
\begin{ex}[A complete residue system modulo $7$]
The integers
\[
-12,\ -4,\ 11,\ 13,\ 22,\ 82,\ 91
\]
form a complete residue system modulo $7$, since
\[
-12\equiv 2,\quad -4\equiv 3,\quad 11\equiv 4,\quad 13\equiv 6,\quad 22\equiv 1,\quad 82\equiv 5,\quad 91\equiv 0
\qquad (\bmod\,7),
\]
which are exactly the residues $0,1,2,3,4,5,6$ in some order.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

\begin{pro}[How to recognize a complete residue system] \label{pro:complete_criterion}
A set of $n$ integers $\{a_1,\ldots,a_n\}$ is a complete residue system modulo $n$
if and only if no two of them are congruent modulo $n$.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
($\Rightarrow$) If two different $a_i,a_j$ were congruent, then they would represent the same residue class, so some residue class would be missed. That contradicts completeness.

($\Leftarrow$) If no two are congruent, then the $n$ integers lie in $n$ distinct residue classes.
But there are only $n$ residue classes modulo $n$ (namely $[0]_n,\ldots,[n-1]_n$), so they must hit every class exactly once.
\end{proof}

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Congruence and remainders}

\begin{thm}[Same remainder $\Longleftrightarrow$ congruent] \label{thm:cong_remainder}
For integers $a,b$ and $n>1$,
\[
a\equiv b\pmod n
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
a \text{ and } b \text{ leave the same (nonnegative) remainder when divided by } n.
\]
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
Write $b=qn+r$ with $0\le r<n$. If $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then $a=b+kn=(q+k)n+r$, so $a$ leaves the same remainder $r$.

Conversely, if $a=q_1n+r$ and $b=q_2n+r$ with the same remainder $r$, then
$a-b=(q_1-q_2)n$, so $n|(a-b)$ and hence $a\equiv b\pmod n$.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{Basic properties of congruence (congruence arithmetic)}

\begin{thm}[Congruence behaves like equality] \label{thm:basic_cong_props}
Fix $n>1$. For any integers $a,b,c,d$:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a\equiv a\pmod n$.
\item If $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then $b\equiv a\pmod n$.
\item If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $b\equiv c\pmod n$, then $a\equiv c\pmod n$.
\item If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c\equiv d\pmod n$, then
\[
a+c\equiv b+d\pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ac\equiv bd\pmod n.
\]
\item If $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then for any integer $c$,
\[
a+c\equiv b+c\pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ac\equiv bc\pmod n.
\]
\item If $a\equiv b\pmod n$, then $a^k\equiv b^k\pmod n$ for every positive integer $k$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
(1) $n|(a-a)$.

(2) If $n|(a-b)$ then $n|(b-a)=-(a-b)$.

(3) If $a-b=kn$ and $b-c=\ell n$, then $a-c=(k+\ell)n$.

(4) For addition:
\[
(a+c)-(b+d)=(a-b)+(c-d),
\]
a sum of multiples of $n$.
For multiplication, write $a=b+kn$ and $c=d+\ell n$. Then
\[
ac=(b+kn)(d+\ell n)=bd + (b\ell + dk + k\ell n)n,
\]
so $ac-bd$ is divisible by $n$.

(5) Take $d=c$ in (4) for the addition statement, and $d=c$ in (4) for the multiplication statement.

(6) Induct on $k$. The case $k=1$ is given. Assume $a^k\equiv b^k\pmod n$.
Then (4) with $c=a^k$ and $d=b^k$ gives
\[
a^{k+1}=a\cdot a^k \equiv b\cdot b^k=b^{k+1}\pmod n.
\]
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}[Standard workflow]
To compute a complicated expression modulo $n$, repeatedly replace each integer by its least nonnegative residue in $\{0,1,\ldots,n-1\}$ and simplify, using Theorem \ref{thm:basic_cong_props} to justify every replacement.
\end{rem}

\small
\begin{ex}[Showing $41\mid 2^{20}-1$]
We compute modulo $41$.
First, $2^5=32\equiv -9\pmod{41}$. Hence
\[
2^{20}=(2^5)^4 \equiv (-9)^4 \pmod{41}.
\]
Now $(-9)^4 = (9^2)^2 = 81^2$. But $81\equiv -1\pmod{41}$, so $81^2\equiv (-1)^2\equiv 1\pmod{41}$.
Thus $2^{20}\equiv 1\pmod{41}$, and therefore
\[
2^{20}-1 \equiv 0 \pmod{41},
\]
so $41\mid 2^{20}-1$.
\end{ex}

\begin{ex}[A factorial sum modulo $12$]
Find the remainder when
\[
1!+2!+3!+\cdots+100!
\]
is divided by $12$.
Since $4!=24\equiv 0\pmod{12}$, we have $k!\equiv 0\pmod{12}$ for all $k\ge 4$.
Therefore the whole sum is congruent to
\[
1!+2!+3! = 1+2+6 = 9 \pmod{12},
\]
so the remainder is $9$.
\end{ex}
\normalsize

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\subsection*{A warning about cancellation}

\begin{rem}[You cannot always cancel]
Even if $ca\equiv cb\pmod n$, it does \emph{not} necessarily follow that $a\equiv b\pmod n$.
For example,
\[
2\cdot 4 \equiv 2\cdot 1 \pmod 6
\]
(both sides are $8\equiv 2\pmod 6$), but $4\not\equiv 1\pmod 6$.
So cancellation requires extra conditions.
\end{rem}

\begin{thm}[Cancellation law (optional preview)] \label{thm:cancellation_preview}
If $ca\equiv cb\pmod n$, then $a\equiv b\pmod{\,n/d\,}$, where $d=\gcd(c,n)$.
In particular, if $\gcd(c,n)=1$, then cancellation is valid modulo $n$:
\[
ca\equiv cb\pmod n \ \ \text{and}\ \ \gcd(c,n)=1
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
a\equiv b\pmod n.
\]
\end{thm}

\begin{rem}
This theorem explains two common phenomena:
\begin{itemize}
\item Cancellation may still be possible, but sometimes the modulus changes.
\item A product can be congruent to $0$ even when neither factor is congruent to $0$ (e.g.\ $4\cdot 3\equiv 0\pmod{12}$).
\end{itemize}
We will return to proofs of such results after developing gcd techniques more fully.
\end{rem}

\bigskip

% ------------------------------------------------------------
\small
\begin{exer} \label{exer:equiv_cong}
~
\begin{enumerate}
% --- Equivalence relations ---
\item On $\mathbb{R}$ define $x\,R\,y \iff y=x^2$. Determine $\operatorname{Dom}(R)$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(R)$.
\item For each relation below, determine whether it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive:
\begin{enumerate}
\item On $\mathbb{R}$, $x\sim y \iff x\le y$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$, $x\sim y \iff xy>0$.
\item On $\mathbb{R}$, $x\sim y \iff \lfloor x\rfloor=\lfloor y\rfloor$.
\end{enumerate}
\item Define $x\sim y$ on $\mathbb{R}$ by $x-y\in\mathbb{Z}$. Show that $\sim$ is an equivalence relation and describe the equivalence class $[x]$.

% --- Burton-style basic congruence skills (no gcd/lcm required) ---
\item Prove: If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $m\mid n$, then $a\equiv b\pmod m$.
\item Prove: If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $c>0$, then $ca\equiv cb\pmod{cn}$.
\item Prove: If $a\equiv b\pmod n$ and $a,b,n$ are all divisible by $d>0$, then
\[
\frac{a}{d}\equiv \frac{b}{d}\pmod{\frac{n}{d}}.
\]

\item Give an example showing that $a^2\equiv b^2\pmod n$ need not imply $a\equiv b\pmod n$.

\item Find the remainders when $2^{50}$ and $41^{65}$ are divided by $7$.

\item What is the remainder when the sum
\[
1^5+2^5+3^5+\cdots+99^5+100^5
\]
is divided by $4$?

\item Prove that $53^{103}+10^{353}$ is divisible by $39$, and that $111^{333}+333^{111}$ is divisible by $7$.

\item For $n\ge 1$, use congruences to prove:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $7 \mid 5^{2n} + 3\cdot 2^{5n-2}$.
\item $13 \mid 3^{n+2} + 4^{2n+1}$.
\item $27 \mid 2^{5n+1} + 5^{n+2}$.
\item $43 \mid 6^{n+2} + 7^{2n+1}$.
\end{enumerate}

\item For $n\ge 1$, show that
\[
(-13)^{n+1}\equiv (-13)^n+(-13)^{n-1}\pmod{181}.
\]
(\textit{Hint:} First check that $(-13)^2\equiv -13+1\pmod{181}$, then use induction on $n$.)

\item Prove the following:
\begin{enumerate}
\item For any integer $a$, $a^3\equiv 0,1,$ or $6\pmod 7$.
\item For any integer $a$, $a^4\equiv 0$ or $1\pmod 5$.
\item If $a$ is not divisible by $2$ or $3$, then $a^2\equiv 1\pmod{24}$.
\end{enumerate}

\item Let $p$ be a prime with $n<p<2n$. Show that
\[
\binom{2n}{n}\equiv 0\pmod p.
\]

\item Verify that $0,1,2,2^2,2^3,\ldots,2^9$ form a complete residue system modulo $11$.
Show also that $0,1^2,2^2,3^2,\ldots,10^2$ do \emph{not} form a complete residue system modulo $11$.

\item Prove directly (without gcd) that any $n$ consecutive integers form a complete residue system modulo $n$.
Deduce that the product of any $n$ consecutive integers is divisible by $n$.

\item Use congruences to verify that
\[
89\mid 2^{44}-1
\qquad\text{and}\qquad
97\mid 2^{48}-1.
\]

% --- Additional harder problems (still avoiding gcd/lcm dependence) ---
\item Show that for any integer $t$, the number $t^5-t$ is divisible by $30$.

\item Find the remainder when $7^{2026}$ is divided by $100$.

\item Prove that for any integer $n$,
\[
n^3-n \text{ is divisible by }3
\quad\text{and}\quad
n^5-n \text{ is divisible by }5.
\]
(For the second, use least nonnegative residues modulo $5$.)

\item ({\bf Hard}) Let $p$ be prime. Prove that $p$ divides $\binom{p}{k}$ for $1\le k\le p-1$.
Deduce that for all integers $a,b$,
\[
(a+b)^p \equiv a^p+b^p \pmod p.
\]

\item ({\bf Very Hard}) Prove that for every integer $t$, the number $t^7-t$ is divisible by $42$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{exer}
\normalsize
% ============================================================
```

parts: At the end of the main exposition, relate the notion of congruence classes to equivalence classes and discuss how congruence arithmetic corresponds to performing arithmetic on congruence classes. Give me this part as a subsection, do not need to reproduce the earlier exposition

thoughts.summary: Explaining congruence classes and arithmetic on classes
thoughts.content: User wants a subsection on congruence classes as equivalence classes, discussing arithmetic on them and well-definedness, using LaTeX. I'll tie it to previous discussions on equivalence relations, showing congruence mod n is an equivalence relation. Then, I'll define class arithmetic and prove its well-definedness.
chunks: User wants a subsection on congruence classes as equivalence classes, discussing arithmetic on them and well-definedness, using LaTeX.
I'll tie it to previous discussions on equivalence relations, showing congruence mod n is an equivalence relation.
Then, I'll define class arithmetic and prove its well-definedness.

thoughts.content: In the quotient set \( \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \), arithmetic is performed by usual operations followed by projection. The map \( \pi: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \) is a surjective homomorphism. Choosing least nonnegative residues gives canonical representatives. However, caution is needed: cancellation doesn’t always work unless \( n \) is prime.
chunks: In the quotient set \( \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \), arithmetic is performed by usual operations followed by projection.
The map \( \pi: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \) is a surjective homomorphism.
Choosing least nonnegative residues gives canonical representatives.
However, caution is needed: cancellation doesn’t always work unless \( n \) is prime.

parts:
```latex
\subsection*{Congruence classes as equivalence classes; arithmetic on classes}

\noindent
Fix $n>1$. Earlier we introduced the general idea of an \emph{equivalence relation} on a set and its \emph{equivalence classes}.
Congruence modulo $n$ is exactly such an equivalence relation on $\mathbb{Z}$:
\[
a \equiv b \pmod n \quad \Longleftrightarrow \quad n\mid (a-b).
\]
Therefore, the sets
\[
[a]_n \;=\;\{\, x\in\mathbb{Z} : x\equiv a\pmod n \,\}
\]
are precisely the \textbf{equivalence classes} of this relation. The collection of all congruence classes is the quotient set
\[
\mathbb{Z}/\!\equiv\pmod n=\{[0]_n,[1]_n,\ldots,[n-1]_n\},
\]
where $0,1,\ldots,n-1$ may be taken as canonical representatives (the least nonnegative residues).

\bigskip

\noindent
The key point is that \textbf{congruence arithmetic is just ordinary arithmetic performed on these classes}.
We define addition and multiplication of congruence classes by
\[
[a]_n+[b]_n \;:=\; [a+b]_n,
\qquad
[a]_n\cdot[b]_n \;:=\; [ab]_n.
\]
To make sense, we must check that these definitions do \emph{not} depend on the chosen representatives.

\begin{pro}[Well-defined operations on classes]
Suppose $a\equiv a'\pmod n$ and $b\equiv b'\pmod n$. Then
\[
a+b \equiv a'+b' \pmod n
\quad\text{and}\quad
ab \equiv a'b' \pmod n.
\]
Consequently,
\[
[a+b]_n=[a'+b']_n
\quad\text{and}\quad
[ab]_n=[a'b']_n,
\]
so $[a]_n+[b]_n$ and $[a]_n\cdot[b]_n$ are well-defined.
\end{pro}

\begin{proof}
This is exactly the basic compatibility of congruence with addition and multiplication:
from $a\equiv a'\pmod n$ and $b\equiv b'\pmod n$ we get $a+b\equiv a'+b'\pmod n$ and $ab\equiv a'b'\pmod n$.
Therefore the resulting classes are equal.
\end{proof}

\bigskip

\noindent
In practice, this is why we are allowed to compute ``mod $n$'' by repeatedly replacing an integer with any congruent one (especially its least nonnegative residue): we are simply choosing different representatives for the \emph{same} congruence class, and the final class (hence final remainder) does not change.

\begin{rem}[What reduction really means]
When you write something like
\[
17 \equiv 5 \pmod{12},
\]
you are saying the two integers represent the same class: $[17]_{12}=[5]_{12}$.
Thus, doing
\[
9+8=17 \equiv 5\pmod{12}
\]
is the same as computing in classes:
\[
[9]_{12}+[8]_{12}=[17]_{12}=[5]_{12}.
\]
\end{rem}

\begin{rem}[Cancellation and ``zero divisors'']
Because we are working with classes, cancellation can fail: it may happen that
\[
[a]_n\cdot[b]_n=[0]_n
\quad\text{even though}\quad
[a]_n\ne[0]_n\ \text{and}\ [b]_n\ne[0]_n.
\]
This is the class-based reason behind examples like $4\cdot 3\equiv 0\pmod{12}$.
(When $n$ is prime, this pathology disappears for nonzero classes: every nonzero class has a multiplicative inverse, so cancellation becomes valid among nonzero classes.)
\end{rem}
```

thoughts.summary: Handling citation for snippet with image
thoughts.content: The `msearch` returned a good chunk, but the formatted snippet from page 99 with exercise 3.2.15 includes garbled lines.
