parts:
Below is the list of **modular-arithmetic examples/problems** in the Larson handout that **do not require** the **greatest common divisor (GCD)** / **least common multiple (LCM)** machinery and **do not involve matrix determinants**. (I’ll also note the excluded items at the end for clarity.) fileciteturn9file0

## Included (no GCD/LCM, no determinants)

### Pigeonhole / “congruence classes” arguments
- **3.2.1**: Any subset of 55 numbers from \(\{1,\dots,100\}\) contains two numbers differing by \(9\). (Uses congruence classes mod \(9\) + pigeonhole.) fileciteturn9file0  
- **3.2.5**: For any set of \(n\) integers, some nonempty subset has sum divisible by \(n\). (Pigeonhole proof via partial sums \(y_i\).) fileciteturn7file0L157-L157  
- **3.2.11**: Any subset of 55 numbers chosen from \(\{1,\dots,100\}\) must contain differences \(10,12,13\) (but need not contain \(11\)). (Combinatorial; can be treated with residue-class/pigeonhole style.) fileciteturn9file0  

### “Compute via remainders” / basic modular calculations
- **3.2.2**: With \(N=22\cdot31+11\cdot17+13\cdot19\), determine (a) parity, (b) units digit, (c) remainder mod \(7\), **without** computing \(N\) directly. fileciteturn9file0  
- **3.2.3**: Last two digits of \(3^{1234}\) (work mod \(100\)). fileciteturn9file0  

### Quadratic residues / “work mod \(m\)” divisibility
- **3.2.6**: If \(2n+1\) and \(3n+1\) are perfect squares, then \(n\) is divisible by \(40\). (Uses squares mod \(5\) and mod \(8\).) fileciteturn7file0L157-L157 fileciteturn7file0L206-L206  
- **3.2.14 (a,c,d,e)**: Several divisibility problems suited to modular arithmetic (e.g. powers mod \(3\), mod \(7\), polynomial divisibility by \(12\), and a larger-number congruence/divisibility claim). fileciteturn9file0  

### Higher-difficulty modular problem set (99–100)
All of these are modular-arithmetic style and **do not invoke determinants**; they also **do not require GCD/LCM**, except where explicitly noted.
- **3.2.15 (a–f)**: Mod \(4\) / parity / squares-type arguments; includes a power-divisibility item \(2^{70}+3^{70}\) divisible by \(13\); and a Diophantine constraint via mod \(4\). fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.16 (a–d)**: Modular restrictions in Diophantine settings (e.g. cube-sum congruence mod \(7\); primality constraint leading to \(n\equiv 3\pmod6\); mod \(24\) structure; perfect-square constraints implying \(24\mid m\)). fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.17**: A closure property on a set of primes forces the set to be empty (hint suggests working mod \(7\)). fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.18**: No integer solutions to \(x^2+3xy-2y^2=122\) (hint: discriminant mod \(17\)). fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.19**: For any integer \(n\), find an integer made only of digits \(0\) and \(1\) divisible by \(n\). (Classic pigeonhole construction.) fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.20**: If \(n\) divides one Fibonacci number, it divides infinitely many Fibonacci numbers. (Can be handled by modular recurrence / induction.) fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.22**: A “reversal” polynomial congruence mod \(5\): from \(am^3+bm^2+cm+d\equiv 0\pmod5\) (with \(5\nmid d\)), deduce existence of \(n\) with \(dn^3+cn^2+bn+a\equiv 0\pmod5\). fileciteturn7file0L451-L452  
- **3.2.23**: \((21n-3)/4\) and \((15n+2)/4\) cannot both be integers for the same \(n\). (Mod \(4\) obstruction.) fileciteturn9file0  
- **3.2.24 (a,b)**: Existence questions about consecutive integers with “unique divisors” properties (more divisor-combinatorics than pure congruences, but still in this section and does not require GCD/LCM/determinants). fileciteturn9file0  

## Excluded (because they *do* use GCD/LCM/relative primality, CRT, or determinants)
- **3.2.4** (solution explicitly uses “relatively prime” + Bézout-type identity). fileciteturn9file0  
- **3.2.8** (Chinese remainder theorem), **3.2.9** (uses CRT), **3.2.10** (uses \(\gcd(x,y)\)). fileciteturn7file0L346-L346  
- **3.2.12–3.2.13** (determinants / matrix singularity via mod \(2\)). fileciteturn9file0  
- **3.2.21** (modular inverse existence iff relatively prime). fileciteturn7file0L451-L451  
- **3.2.25–3.2.26** (explicit pairwise relatively prime assumption / completion of a GCD-based proof). fileciteturn9file0  

If you want, I can also reformat the **included** items into a clean “problem bank” (just statements, sorted by technique: pigeonhole / residues / parity / higher-power cycles), keeping the same numbering.
reformat the included items into a clean “problem bank”, LaTex

parts:
```latex
% ============================================================
% Problem Bank (Larson, Section 3.2): Modular Arithmetic
% Filtered to exclude items requiring gcd/lcm machinery or matrix determinants.
% ============================================================

\begin{exer}[Problem Bank: Modular Arithmetic (Larson, selected)]
~
\begin{enumerate}

\item[\textbf{3.2.1.}]
Prove that any subset of $55$ numbers chosen from the set $\{1,2,3,\ldots,100\}$ must contain two numbers differing by $9$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.2.}]
Let
\[
N = 22\cdot 31 + 11\cdot 17 + 13\cdot 19.
\]
Determine:
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item the parity of $N$;
\item the units digit of $N$;
\item the remainder when $N$ is divided by $7$.
\end{enumerate}
(\emph{Do this without actually computing $N$.})

\item[\textbf{3.2.3.}]
What are the last two digits of $3^{1234}$?

\item[\textbf{3.2.5.}]
Prove that for any set of $n$ integers, there is a subset of them whose sum is divisible by $n$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.6.}]
Prove that if $2n+1$ and $3n+1$ are both perfect squares, then $n$ is divisible by $40$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.11.}]
Prove that any subset of $55$ numbers chosen from the set $\{1,2,3,\ldots,100\}$ must contain numbers differing by $10$, $12$, and $13$,
but need not contain a pair differing by $11$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.14.}]
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item Show that $2^{2x+1}+1$ is divisible by $3$.
\item Prove or disprove: $2^x \equiv 2^y \pmod n$ if $x \equiv y \pmod n$.
\item Show that $4^{3x+1}+2^{3x+1}+1$ is divisible by $7$.
\item If $n>0$, prove that $12$ divides $n^4-4n^3+5n^2-2n$.
\item Prove that $(2903)^n-(803)^n-(464)^n+(261)^n$ is divisible by $1897$.
\end{enumerate}

\item[\textbf{3.2.15.}]
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item Prove that no prime three more than a multiple of four is a sum of two squares. (\emph{Hint: Work modulo $4$.})
\item Prove that the sequence (in base-10 notation)
\[
11,\ 111,\ 1111,\ 11111,\ \ldots
\]
contains no squares.
\item Prove that the difference of the squares of any two odd numbers is exactly divisible by $8$.
\item Prove that $2^{70}+3^{70}$ is divisible by $13$.
\item Prove that the sum of two odd squares cannot be a square.
\item Determine all integral solutions of
\[
a^2+b^2+c^2=a^2b^2.
\]
(\emph{Hint: Analyze modulo $4$.})
\end{enumerate}

\item[\textbf{3.2.16.}]
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item If $x^3+y^3=z^3$ has a solution in integers $x,y,z$, show that one of the three must be a multiple of $7$.
\item If $n$ is a positive integer greater than $1$ such that $2^n+n^2$ is prime, show that $n\equiv 3\pmod 6$.
\item Let $x$ be an integer one less than a multiple of $24$. Prove that if $a$ and $b$ are positive integers such that $ab=x$, then $a+b$ is a multiple of $24$.
\item Prove that if $n^2+m$ and $n^2-m$ are perfect squares, then $m$ is divisible by $24$.
\end{enumerate}

\item[\textbf{3.2.17.}]
Let $S$ be a set of primes such that $a,b\in S$ (with $a$ and $b$ not necessarily distinct) implies $ab+4\in S$.
Show that $S$ must be empty. (\emph{Hint: One approach is to work modulo $7$.})

\item[\textbf{3.2.18.}]
Prove that there are no integers $x$ and $y$ for which
\[
x^2+3xy-2y^2=122.
\]
(\emph{Hint: Use the quadratic equation to solve for $x$, then look at the discriminant modulo $17$. Can it ever be a perfect square?})

\item[\textbf{3.2.19.}]
Given an integer $n$, show that an integer can always be found which contains only the digits $0$ and $1$ (in base $10$) and which is divisible by $n$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.20.}]
Show that if $n$ divides a single Fibonacci number, then it will divide infinitely many Fibonacci numbers.

\item[\textbf{3.2.22.}]
Let $a,b,c,d$ be fixed integers with $d$ not divisible by $5$.
Assume that $m$ is an integer for which
\[
am^3+bm^2+cm+d
\]
is divisible by $5$.
Prove that there exists an integer $n$ for which
\[
dn^3+cn^2+bn+a
\]
is also divisible by $5$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.23.}]
Prove that $(21n-3)/4$ and $(15n+2)/4$ cannot both be integers for the same positive integer $n$.

\item[\textbf{3.2.24.}]
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item Do there exist $n$ consecutive integers for which the $j$th integer, $1\le j\le n$, has a divisor which does not divide any other member of the sequence?
\item Do there exist $n$ consecutive integers for which the $j$th integer, $1\le j\le n$, has at least $j$ divisors, none of which divides any other member of the sequence?
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}
\end{exer}
```

parts:
Here is a clean, modular-arithmetic solution (no \(\gcd\)/\(\mathrm{lcm}\) machinery needed).

---

**Claim.** There is no nonempty set \(S\) of primes such that  
\[
a,b\in S \ \Longrightarrow\ ab+4\in S
\]
(with \(a,b\) allowed to be equal). Hence \(S=\varnothing\).

### Proof
Assume for contradiction that \(S\neq\varnothing\).

1) **\(7\notin S\).**  
If \(7\in S\), then taking \(a=b=7\) gives
\[
7\cdot 7+4=53\in S.
\]
Now taking \(a=7\) and \(b=53\) gives
\[
7\cdot 53+4 = 371+4=375 = 3\cdot 5^3,
\]
which is not prime—contradiction. So \(7\notin S\).

2) **From any \(p\in S\), we can generate an element of \(S\) that is \(\equiv 1\pmod 7\).**  
Pick any \(p\in S\). Define a sequence in \(S\) by repeatedly using \(a=b\):
\[
x_0:=p,\qquad x_{k+1}:=x_k^2+4 \quad (k\ge 0).
\]
Each \(x_{k+1}\in S\) because \(x_{k+1}=x_k\cdot x_k+4\).

If \(p\neq 7\), then modulo \(7\) we have \(p\equiv \pm1,\pm2,\pm3\). Check:
- If \(x\equiv \pm2\pmod 7\), then \(x^2+4\equiv 4+4\equiv 1\pmod 7\).
- If \(x\equiv \pm1\pmod 7\), then \(x^2+4\equiv 1+4\equiv 5\pmod 7\), and then \(5^2+4\equiv 25+4\equiv 4+4\equiv 1\pmod 7\).
- If \(x\equiv \pm3\pmod 7\), then \(x^2+4\equiv 9+4\equiv 2+4\equiv 6\pmod 7\), then \(6^2+4\equiv 36+4\equiv 1+4\equiv 5\pmod 7\), then \(5^2+4\equiv 1\pmod 7\).

So after at most three steps, we get some \(x\in S\) with
\[
x\equiv 1\pmod 7.
\]

3) **From an element \(\equiv 1\pmod 7\), we force \(7\in S\).**  
Fix such an \(x\in S\) with \(x\equiv 1\pmod 7\). Define
\[
y_0:=x,\qquad y_{k+1}:=x\,y_k+4 \quad (k\ge 0).
\]
Again each \(y_{k+1}\in S\) since it has the form \(ab+4\) with \(a=x\in S\) and \(b=y_k\in S\).

Reduce modulo \(7\). Because \(x\equiv 1\pmod 7\),
\[
y_{k+1}\equiv x\,y_k+4 \equiv y_k+4 \pmod 7.
\]
Starting from \(y_0\equiv 1\pmod 7\), we get the chain of residues
\[
y_0\equiv 1,\ 
y_1\equiv 5,\ 
y_2\equiv 2,\ 
y_3\equiv 6,\ 
y_4\equiv 3,\ 
y_5\equiv 0
\pmod 7.
\]
Thus \(y_5\in S\) and \(7\mid y_5\). Since \(y_5\) is prime, it must be \(y_5=7\). Hence \(7\in S\).

But this contradicts step (1), which showed \(7\notin S\). Therefore our assumption \(S\neq\varnothing\) is false, so \(S=\varnothing\).

\(\square\)
can you paraphase this question better? Going a roubabout way of defining S by saying S is a set of primes such that .... ..... and then asking to show S is actually empty is not good

Here are several cleaner paraphrases that avoid the “define \(S\) then show it’s empty” whiplash, while keeping the same mathematical content.

### Option A (most direct)
**Show that no nonempty set of primes is closed under the operation \((a,b)\mapsto ab+4\).**  
More precisely: prove there does not exist a nonempty set \(S\) of primes such that for all \(a,b\in S\) (allowing \(a=b\)), the number \(ab+4\) is also a prime in \(S\).

### Option B (as a “closure property” impossibility)
**Prove that a closure property is impossible for primes.**  
Assume \(S\) is a collection of primes with the property that whenever \(a\) and \(b\) are in \(S\), the integer \(ab+4\) is again a prime (hence also in \(S\)). Prove that this assumption leads to a contradiction.

### Option C (framed as “no infinite prime-generating rule of this kind”)
**A prime-generating rule that cannot persist.**  
Suppose you start with some primes and repeatedly apply the rule “from \(a\) and \(b\), produce \(ab+4\)”. Prove that it is impossible for this process to stay within the primes forever (i.e., at some stage \(ab+4\) must be composite), no matter what starting primes you choose.

### Option D (minimalist, contest style)
Let \(S\) be a nonempty set of primes. Suppose that for every \(a,b\in S\), the number \(ab+4\) is also prime. Prove that such an \(S\) cannot exist.

### Option E (more “reader-friendly narrative”)
**Impossible closure among primes.**  
Is it possible to pick a set of primes \(S\) so that multiplying any two primes from the set and adding \(4\) always yields another prime in the same set? Prove that the answer is no.

If you tell me the tone you want (Olympiad/AMC-ish vs textbook vs enrichment), I’ll pick the best one and adjust wording accordingly.
